bibl.title: Letter from Leonard Wood to John Dalzell, December 31, 1901

div1.p: Wood advocates a pension for Mabel Houston Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Leonard Wood to John Dalzell, December 31, 1901
div1.opener:
COPY.
HEADQUARTERS
MILITARY GOVERNOR
ISLAND OF CUBA
HAVANA
December 31, 1901
Hon. John Dlazell.
Member of Congress.
Washington. D. C.
My dear Mr. Dalzell:-
div1.p:
I have just received a letter from Mrs. Lazear
whose husband died from yellow fever acquired while engaged as a
member of the yellow fever commission investigating the cause of the
transmission of yellow fever.

This officer's work was of the greatest value and he sacrificed
his life in the pursuit of this investigation. It is needless to
say that the result of the work of this commission is one of incal-
culable value to humanity and especially to the people of the
Southern states. I believe the result of their work will render it
possible for us to control yellow fever in the future which means
the saving of millions of dollars per year and enormous number of
lives.

I feel that the widow of Dr. Lazear is fully entitled to a pen-
sion and that his services entitle him to this mark of consideration
from his countrymen. I doubt if any men have been engaged in recent
years on any work more important and obtained more valuable results
than the members of this commission and it is only right and just
that the family of the member of the commission who lost his life
should receive every consideration granted by the pension laws.

I most strongly commend this case to your favorable considera-
tion.
